channel.title: Interesting Things on Beng Tan
channel.description: Recent content in Interesting Things on Beng Tan

item.title: Interesting Things #8 ‚Äî Meta-/beta-stability
item.description:
The lastest issue of Interesting Things is subscriber-only. Please come back in a few days time.

If you don’t want to wait, subscribe to get it in your inbox now!

Look at some older issues.

item.title: Interesting Things #7 ‚Äî Don't read everything
item.description:
Hi,

This is Beng Tan and welcome to Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie biz, science, and related fields.

I got interesting feedback this week. Someone said they get overwhelmed if a newsletter has tons and tons of info in it. They were referring to this one. üò®

But I’ll take this as a compliment. üòÅ

And I will say: Don’t read everything. Just read what you find interesting and skip the rest. It’s a newsletter. It’s not gonna vanish into your social media feed. You can always come back later. Or not at all.

Oh, and don’t read it all in a day. Spread it out over a week. Relax.

I hope you find the following stories interesting. If you don’t, you can [unsubscribe]({{ unsubscribe_url }}) and I won’t pollute your inbox again.

Happy reading!

#tech

What’s in email tracking links and pixels? ‚Äî An attempt to deconstruct tracking links and pixels and highlight the data that is being collected.

Extrapolating to Unnatural Language Processing with GPT-3’s In-context Learning: The Good, the Bad, and the Mysterious ‚Äî Something that wasn‚Äôt apparent in smaller models seems to ‚Äúemerge" as models get bigger.

UnixShell Programming: The Next 50 Years [pdf] ‚Äî Improving the shell holds much promise for development, ops, and data processing.

The ARM processor (Thumb-2), part 1: Introduction ‚Äî How does Windows 10 use this processor in user mode?

New CSS functional pseudo-class selectors :is() and :where() ‚Äî These seemingly small additions to CSS selector syntax are going to have a big impact.

Livebook is a secret weapon for documentation ‚Äî A new way to provide documentation, interactive exploration, and expose the app logic in a way we couldn’t before.

Failing Big with Elixir and LiveView ‚Äî A post-mortem of why a political party in Germany had to delay their convention by an hour.

Structural Typing in Rust ‚Äî Bringing structurally typed functions to Rust via LabelledGeneric.

Tightness Driven Development in Rust ‚Äî The tightness of a type is the proportion of invariants that are upheld in the type definition as opposed to its methods.

Write Rust lints without forking Clippy ‚Äî Dylint makes it easy for developers to maintain their own personal lint collections.

Testing in the Twenties (May 2021) ‚Äî A compelling argument in favour of taking automated testing seriously.

On the Diverse And Fantastical Shapes of Testing ‚Äî Martin Fowler on the meaning of unit testing.

Logging is important ‚Äî Having good logs requires a little bit of thought and consistency. But is not that hard.

Please don’t count outages (or SEVs, or whatever) ‚Äî When a metric becomes a goal, it ceases to be useful.

Making JavaScript run fast on WebAssembly ‚Äî Optimising javascript performance for new environments (other than the browser).

Is WebAssembly magic performance pixie dust? ‚Äî There is something to gain from taking a piece of JavaScript, turning it into AssemblyScript and compiling it to WebAssembly.

Leaky Abstractions ‚Äî While deleting a file from a disk is usually trivial., deleting from certain ZIP files is extremely slow.

SQL Query Optimization: Understanding Key Principle ‚Äî Gain a true understanding of SQL query speeds, incuding a demonstration of slow and fast query types

syscall & sysret ‚Äî How syscall or sysret is implemented on WingOS by a 14-year old.

About Yak Shaving ‚Äî The story of how I started doing open source.

The Future Web: Will Canvas Rendering Replace the DOM? ‚Äî Google Docs is switching to canvas rendering. WebAssembly is growing. Are we moving to a future of opaque binary blobs?

The startups reinventing the web browser ‚Äî The web browser is a crucial part of modern life, and yet it hasn’t really been revised since the ’90s. That may be about to change.

Contributing to Gemini ecosystem ‚Äî A glimpse into what’s happening in this next-gen platform.

Analysis report of the Facefish rootkit ‚Äî Facefish can be characterized as a backdoor for Linux platform.

Running the 1G Analog Phone from 1997 ‚Äî Someone created a 1G cellular network with a laptop and commonly available hardware.

Joseph Weizenbaum’s Original ELIZA ‚Äî A storied part of tech history.

Three Embarrassing Software Engineering Fails ‚Äî The biggest mistakes I made in my career‚Ää, ‚Ääand what I learned.

Behind the painstaking process of creating Chinese computer fonts ‚Äî More than 40 years ago, designers drew and edited thousands of characters by hand to make it possible to type and print in Chinese.

How Lois Lew mastered IBM‚Äôs 1940s Chinese typewriter ‚Äî She memorised 5,400 (non-unicode) code points.

Conditional HTTP GET: The fastest requests need no response body ‚Äî A great guide on how conditional http headers interact with the browser cache.

Offload Mental Simulation ‚Äî Is this an essential feature for all future programming systems?

#indie biz

Be Decision-Driven Not Data-Driven ‚Äî The tech media is obsessed with data but maybe being data-driven is the wrong goal.

How to raise for the first time ‚Äî You may find our learnings handy if you’re an early stage startup looking to raise.

SaaS Fundraising Handbook ‚Äî Be Fully Prepared for Your Company‚Äôs Next Fundraise.

Meet Your Next Angel Investor. They’re 19 ‚Äî It‚Äôs never been easier to invest in startups, and Gen Z is taking full advantage.

#science

Sick bats also employ ‘social distancing’ which prevents the outbreak of epidemics ‚Äî Bats also resort to isolation which can assist in preventing mass contagion.

How This Zombie Fungus Turns Cicadas into Horror-Movie Sex Bots ‚Äî An amphetamine and a psychedelic help parasitic fungi spread their spores through insects' doomed mating attempts.

Mach 30 ‚Äòtunnel‚Äô will put China decades ahead ‚Äî Hypersonic tech could make it possible for super-fast jets to fly anywhere in the world in two hours or less.

Cities Have Unique Microbial ‘Fingerprints’, First Study of Its Kind Reveals ‚Äî Got sick when you holiday in a new place? You probably got exposed to a new microbiome.

Fifteen Years of Radar Reveal Venus‚Äôs Most Basic Facts ‚Äî Every day on Venus is a different length.

Has the American-Grown Truffle Finally Broken Through? ‚Äî These delicacies, harvested in an experiment in North Carolina, have food-lovers and farmers ravenous for more.

China maintains ‘artificial sun’ at 120 million Celsius for over 100 seconds, setting new world record ‚Äî A key step toward the test running of a fusion reactor.

153 years after discovery of the immune system’s dendritic cells, scientists uncover a new subset

#life

A hacker mindset ‚Äî Rules to help develop what I call ‘a hacker mindset’.

The Digital Nomad Life and the Ambiguous Gift of Freedom ‚Äî Is this lifestyle really as dazzling as it seems?

pencil and paper thinking (Apr 2021) ‚Äî To truly understand the world, we need tools far more powerful than pencil and paper.

Secret Chats Show How Cybergang Became a Ransomware Powerhouse ‚Äî A Russian-speaking outfit called DarkSide offered would-be computer crooks not just the tools, but also customer support.

Moving my US tech job to Australia ‚Äî Another data point in this new trend.

My Personal Creed of Employment ‚Äî I describe the attitude and practices I wish to follow. I hope some of them might help you.

A disturbing, viral Twitter thread reveals how AI-powered insurance can go wrong ‚Äî Lemonade tweeted about what it means to be an AI-first insurance company. It left a sour taste in many customers‚Äô mouths.

Decision Making Bias: Availability ‚Äî We overestimate the likelihood of events that are easier to recall.

MeWork ‚Äî There‚Äôs a new class of billionaire in America which makes their fortunes destroying value rather than creating it.

#random

Everything You Might Want to Know about Whaling ‚Äî I think whaling is really cool. I can‚Äôt help it. I embarked on this project to understand everything I could about whaling.

Pixel Thoughts ‚Äî A 60-second meditation tool to help clear your mind.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, please share this newsletter with 2.9 friends (I’m trying to increase the R0 number).

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me. I’d love to give them some exposure too.

Happy reading!
Beng

item.title: Interesting Things #6 ‚Äî Esoteric languages and sleep sort
item.description:
Hi,

This is Beng Tan and welcome to Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie biz, science, and related fields.

Wow, I’ve only been doing this for about a month and it’s the sixth edition already. Time flies.

This edition has a COVID-related article. I try to stay away from pandemic related news since it’s usually entangled with politics, but this time, I included an article for the science.

I hope you find the following stories interesting. If you don’t, you can [unsubscribe]({{ unsubscribe_url }}) and I won’t pollute your inbox again.

Happy reading!

#tech

A Brief Introduction to Esoteric Languages ‚Äî Weird stuff.

Need Something Sorted? Sleep on It! ‚Äî Sort a list of integers by going to sleep.

Losing control to Kubernetes ‚Äî Having an actual implementation of something is useful in understanding it so I decided it was time to learn something new.

TraNOR - A computer built with transistors (Apr 2021) ‚Äî The CPU consists of 1897 MOSFET transistors. This computer is fast enough to play games on it.

Making sure the things that aren‚Äôt supposed to work don‚Äôt work ‚Äî Remember to test for false positives.

Linux Internals: How /proc/self/mem writes to unwritable memory ‚Äî Writes performed through this file will succeed even if the destination virtual memory is marked unwritable.

Personalized Content Feeds Suck. Curation is a Better, Scalable Alternative ‚Äî Algorithms fail to expand consumer interests despite the deluge of information on the internet.

Stop building websites for iPhones ‚Äî Not everyone can afford the latest iPhone or Galaxy.

Constant-Time Big Numbers: An Introduction (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Timing attacks and how to mitigate them with constant-time code.

What’s a Principal Software Engineer? ‚Äî One of the things I couldn’t answer in the last 4-5 years was my role.

Extreme HTTP Performance Tuning: 1.2M API req/s on a 4 vCPU EC2 Instance ‚Äî The steps that I took to serve 1.2 million JSON API requests per second from a 4 vCPU AWS EC2 instance.

Learn CSS ‚Äî An evergreen CSS course and reference to level up your web styling expertise.

Teardown of a PC power supply ‚Äî Have you ever wondered what’s inside your computer’s power supply?

The tools and tech I use to run a one-woman hardware company ‚Äî A look into the tech and tools used by Winterbloom.

Hacker’s guide to deep-learning side-channel attacks: the theory ‚Äî Learn the concepts behind deep-learning side-channel attacks. Use it to recover AES cryptographic keys.

CHIP-8 (and Emulators) In Plain English ‚Äî Learn about CHIP-8 by writing an emulator for it.

Developing mobile digital key applications with ClojureScript ‚Äî See how we use ClojureScript, React Native via Krell, and Storybook to manage complexity and improve workflow efficiency.

Discovering goroutine leaks with Semgrep ‚Äî This post describes the origins of goroutine leaks and code patterns to detect them. Semgrep rules used to reveal those patterns are released to the public.

Powering the Python Package Index in 2021 (Apr 2021) – What does it take to finance and power PyPI in this current day and age?

Cryptography from the Ground Up ‚Äî Delve into the world of classical cryptography.

When Adobe Stopped Flash Content From Running It Also Stopped A Chinese Railroad (Jan 2021) ‚Äî Dalian‚Äôs railroad network found itself ground to a halt for 20 hours.

Spot instances for personal servers ‚Äî Save 70% on personal servers using one weird trick.

Rust is a wave of the future ‚Äî Dealing with Rust is going to become increasingly necessary for me and a lot of people.

Why are device-independent bitmaps upside down? ‚Äî Something that catches out everybody the first time they encounter it.

Why the sad face? ‚Äî An alternative indenting style for python from a core developer.

All Systems are Human Systems ‚Äî It’s in our best interests to to understand the broader, human scope that systems operate within.

#indie biz

Brainstorming Shopify for SaaS with Travis Fischer ‚Äî What are the lessons learned? Is the opportunity still up for grabs?

#science

Faster than a PCR test: dogs detect Covid in under a second ‚Äî Study in London used six enthusiastic dogs in a double-blind trial.

New Propulsion System Could Enable Flying at Speeds Up to Mach 17 ‚Äî Paving the way for hypersonic flight such as travel from New York to Los Angeles in under 30 minutes.

Stanford researchers make ‚Äòbombshell‚Äô discovery of an entirely new kind of biomolecule ‚Äî A newfound biomolecule could be present in all forms of life and might contribute to autoimmune disease. Another link.

Mysterious fast radio bursts traced to spiral galaxy arms ‚Äî Scientists have traced mysterious fast radio bursts back to their origins and it’s not what they expected.

Robotic ‚ÄòThird Thumb‚Äô use can alter brain representation of the hand ‚Äî Using a robotic ‚ÄòThird Thumb‚Äô can impact how the hand is represented in the brain.

Physicists Identify the Engine Powering Black Hole Energy Beams ‚Äî Supermassive black holes emit jets of white-hot plasma that stretch thousands of light-years across the cosmos.

The Body‚Äôs Most Embarrassing Organ Is an Evolutionary Marvel ‚Äî And yet we have very little idea where anuses come from.

Archaeologists train a neural network to sort pottery fragments for them ‚Äî The network turned out to be as good at the job as human archaeologists.

Incredible Microscope Sees Atoms at Record Resolution ‚Äî The resolution is so fine-tuned, the only blurring that remains is the thermal jiggling of the atoms themselves.

Algae proteins partially restore man’s sight ‚Äî The patient was completely blind before the treatment. Now he can see and count objects on a table.

Research reveals why some find the sound of others eating so irritating ‚Äî Some brains have a stronger link between the part that processes sound and that which controls the mouth and throat

Mathematicians Find Long-Sought Building Blocks for Special Polynomials ‚Äî Hilbert‚Äôs 12th problem asked for novel analogues of the roots of unity, the building blocks for certain number systems.

Solar storms are back, threatening life as we know it on Earth ‚Äî A few days ago, millions of tons of super-heated gas shot from the sun and hurtled towards Earth.

#life

Beware the Copyleft Trolls ‚Äî When photographers sue after Creative Commons Licenses go awry.

How Japanese Technology Shaped Dance Music ‚Äî How did this island nation come to dominate music production and playback?

The Optimal Amount of Hassle ‚Äî What is the optimal amount to put up with so I can still function in a messy and imperfect world?

DeFi Beyond the Hype [pdf] ‚Äî The Emerging World of Decentralized Finance.

The Psychology of Internet Scammers and Frauds ‚Äî I found that many people in the industry were actually pretty ordinary people with homes and children.

Blog about what you’ve struggled with ‚Äî The process I use for a lot of my blog posts.

#random

Map of the Internet 2021 ‚Äî A comprehensive artistic visualization of the Internet as of 2021.

Vortex Spheres ‚Äî Something pretty. Code available.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, please share this newsletter with 2.9 friends (That’s the reproduction number I’m trying to reach).

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me. I’d love to give them some exposure too.

Happy reading!
Beng

item.title: Interesting Things #5 ‚Äî The Last CPU
item.description:
Hi!

Welcome to the fifth edition of Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie business, science, and adjacents.

The following are things I came across during my Internet wanderings. I find them interesting, and I hope you do too.

Happy reading!

#tech

The Last CPU [pdf] ‚Äî As more and more work is offloaded to specialised hardware, should there still be a CPU?

Multiplayer Doom on Cloudflare Workers ‚Äî What if we ported Doom multiplayer to the edge network?

Stopping Time: An Appreciation of Objective-C ‚Äî Savoring one small piece of it one last time before it disappears.

Welcome To The Terrible World Of Prescription-Only Apps ‚Äî Get ready for apps which cost $899 and require a doctor’s prescription (!).

Innovating with Rust ‚Äî How Amazon uses, and contributes to, Rust.

Increasing our development confidence and productivity with Bors ‚Äî How a little GitHub bot keeps our Rust project passing CI in master 100% of the time.

New system cleans messy data tables automatically ‚Äî A new machine learning system uses probabilistic programming to clean dirty datasets and tell you how confident its answers are.

Modern Javascript: Everything you missed over the last 10 years ‚Äî I didn’t cover everything that‚Äôs changed over the last decade, just the items I find most useful.

Incrementally porting a small Python project to Rust (Apr 2021) ‚Äî I ported the project one module at a time, rather than all at once.

Discover CSS polygon shapes ‚Äî Discover new CSS polygon shapes generated with css-doodle and mathematical functions.

Baseline implementations should be predictable ‚Äî Unpredictable code with special cases can perform well on benchmarks, but it‚Äôs hard to tell the difference from real workloads.

Debugging random slow writes in PostgreSQL (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Understanding and mitigating randomly slow writes in PostgreSQL.

Mostly harmless: An account of pseudo-normal floating point numbers ‚Äî Pseudo-normal numbers represent a gap in floating point number classification in the long double format.

How necessary are the programming fundamentals? ‚Äî We’ll introduce the field of algorithms and data structures and show why large companies like Google and Apple are so focused on it.

Weekend hacking: wireless charging for a HP-25 calculator ‚Äî Calculator from 1975? Meet modern wireless charging.

Atomics in AArch64 ‚Äî We‚Äôll look at the performance of a simple atomic operation on a couple of Arm AArch64 machines.

DOM Events ‚Äî Learn how the DOM Event system works through exploration.

The art and science of a great video thumbnail ‚Äî What makes a great thumbnail and how to extract them from videos?

Why do database columns have a character length of 191? ‚Äî 191 is such an odd number. How did we get here?

Codespaces: GitHub’s Play for a Remote Development Future ‚Äî See discussion about remote development halfway through the text.

No, Utility Classes Aren’t the Same As Inline Styles ‚Äî A discussion and contrast of two CSS patterns.

How to look at the stack with gdb ‚Äî A quick walkthrough of how you can use gdb to look at the stack of a C or Rust program.

Language models like GPT-3 could herald a new type of search engine ‚Äî A new idea from researchers could make web search more like talking to human experts.

The Easiest Way to Debug Kubernetes Workloads ‚Äî kubectl debug, a new command, injects a special type of container into problematic Pods and allows you to debug.

Code Quality Metrics Are Guides, Not Goals ‚Äî Measure code quality with metrics, but use the metrics to discover potential opportunities to improve.

#indie biz

Selling Tiny Internet Projects For Fun and Profit ‚Äî How I sold my project Earlyname, how much I sold it for, and how to sell tiny internet projects.

Two months in: How the SaaS that was built in 7 days is going ‚Äî A lot of new developers give up a month later when they fail to net a single upvote. I’m playing a different, long-term game.

How many people continue to use your product six months after they sign up? ‚Äî Before you can begin measuring the number of people who use your app you have to define what ‘using your app’ means.

Micro-Communities - and why you should start one too ‚Äî You don‚Äôt need to create a 5k community from day one. Start with a Micro-Community next time.

Lessons All Founders Can Learn From Slack‚Äôs Famous Second Act ‚Äî Slack’s famous pivot didn’t happen on accident.

#science

From Its Myriad Tips: Mushroom Brain ‚Äî How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds and Shape Our Futures.

If Necessary, Mars Rover Curiosity Could Rip Its Own Wheels Off to Stay Mobile ‚Äî Since wheel wear can’t be avoided, the backup plan is to find a nice sharp rock and use it to rip out the insides of its own wheels.

The Profound Potential of Elon Musk‚Äôs New Rocket ‚Äî An aerospace engineer explains why SpaceX‚Äôs Starship will change everything.

In Mahle’s Contact-Free Electric Motor, Power Reaches the Rotor Wirelessly ‚Äî There’s no wear and tear. No rare earths, either.

Scientists catch exciting magnetic waves in action ‚Äê Researchers have confirmed the existence of magnetic plasma waves in the Sun‚Äôs photosphere.

New Black Hole Math Closes Cosmic Blind Spot ‚Äî A mathematical shortcut for analyzing black hole collisions works even in cases where it shouldn‚Äôt.

Mammals can breathe through anus in emergencies ‚Äî Japanese scientists who studied an unusual method of delivering oxygen in mammals hope to one day try it in people. Another link.

The Largest Cells on Earth (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Deep in the ocean abyss, xenophyophores can grow as large as basketballs.

From apes to birds, there are 65 animal species that ‘laugh’ ‚Äî Laughter is spread widely across mammals and occurs in birds too.

Highest ever energy light captured by Chinese mountain observatory ‚Äî Brightest cosmic light detected on Tibetan Plateau may help rewrite laws of physics. Another link.

Can Machines Control Our Brains? ‚Äî Advances in brain-computer interface technology are impressive, but we‚Äôre not close to anything resembling mind control.

Securing a swift return: how a simple brick can help migratory birds ‚Äî Hollow rectangular bricks help offset habitat loss.

Quantum machine learning hits a limit ‚Äî A new theorem has poked a hole in the accepted understanding about information scrambling.

#life

Inside an International Tech-Support Scam ‚Äî How a computer hacker infiltrated a phone scam operation to expose fraudsters and their schemes.

Why We Need To Adopt The 3-Year Rule Into Our Lives ‚Äî A lot can happen in three years if we stick to something long enough. Or nothing at all if we just let the time slip on by.

Programming and Writing ‚Äî Programming big systems and writing novels have many common traits and similar processes.

Stop Spending Time on Things You Hate (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Your time on Earth is precious and limited. Here‚Äôs how to waste it.

The Memex Method ‚Äî Your blog is a public searchable retrospective database.

Prioritise The Highest Order Bit (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Why focusing on the most important thing often means letting other things blow up.

You Probably Won‚Äôt Change Your Mind After Reading This ‚Äî The availability and understanding of information might not directly shape beliefs and preferences.

Saying the difficult things ‚Äî The valuable part is the flip side of that. It‚Äôs saying the things that are difficult to say, because that‚Äôs what actually builds up the trust.

The Transitory Nature of Content on the Internet ‚Äî We are told that content posted on the Internet lasts forever but nothing is eternal, not even on the Internet.

Avoiding the Frigid Hellscape of Online Marketing ‚Äî An Internet Marketer Offered Me $100 to Betray Myself and My Community.

Using AirTags to detect stationary iPhones ‚Äî Leave an AirTag in a room or house and you can infer whether it’s unoccupied.

the famine of big thinking ‚Äî We build what technology companies, investors, and tech-savvy people want, but not what humans and society need.

Clarity is an underrated skill ‚Äî Being able to define a problem or explain a scenario clearly, precisely and unambiguously is something every developer should strive for.

#random

Spectrogram ‚Äî Music is for everyone. Play with simple experiments that let anyone, of any age, explore how music works.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, I’d love it if you shared this newsletter with a friend or two.

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me! I’d love to give them some exposure too.

Happy reading!
Beng

item.title: Interesting Things #4 ‚Äî Superhistory, Not Superintelligence
item.description:
Hi!

Welcome to the fourth edition of Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie business, science, and adjacents.

(Housekeeping: I recently moved this newsletter from Substack. This is the first edition to be sent out via Buttondown.)

The following are things I came across during my Internet wanderings. I find them interesting, and I hope you do too.

Happy reading!

#tech

Superhistory, Not Superintelligence ‚Äî Simpler algorithms and more data do better than more complex algorithms with less data. What are the implications?

More doorbell adventures ‚Äî Reverse-engineering an internet-enabled doorbell and discovering the code is … meh.

Email explained from first principles ‚Äî Modern email is a patchwork of protocols and extensions. Here is one article to understand them all.

The hidden performance overhead of Python C extensions (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Rewriting python code in a compiled extension is sometimes actually slower.

Dependency Managers Don‚Äôt Manage Your Dependencies ‚Äî Manage front end dependencies yourself instead.

Apparently, You Can Use DNS as a Blazingly Fast Database (Mar 2021) ‚Äî Possible but not advised.

General Guide For Exploring Large Open Source Codebases ‚Äî A general guide to help people with open source contributions.

HDR: Part 1 ‚Äî In this post I‚Äôll cover what high dynamic range (HDR) is and why we care about it.

GitHub repositories to improve skills (Dec 2020) ‚Äî Free programming books, algorithms, public APIs, and much more.

How to optimize ORDER BY RANDOM() ‚Äî Selecting some random rows is an SQL antipattern as databases don‚Äôt have optimizations for this use case.

My second impression of Rust and why I think it’s the best general-purpose language! ‚Äî You won‚Äôt appreciate Rust unless you spend a few weeks building something with it.

What I Learned by Relearning HTML ‚Äî I wondered what I was missing by never learning HTML in a comprehensive way. So I decided to relearn it and discover my unknown unknowns.

Lessons On Writing JavaScript and React From ClojureScript ‚Äî ClojureScript has unlocked whole new levels of productivity in JavaScript and React.

Cryptographic shuffle ‚Äî What if I needed to shuffle a list (or traverse it in a shuffled manner) but couldn’t hold the whole thing in memory?

Ruby Garbage Collection Deep Dive: Compaction ‚Äî Compaction is the solution to fragmentation. Well okay, but what‚Äôs wrong with fragmentation? What is compaction solving?

Reimagining Databases for Vector Embeddings ‚Äî How is a vector database different from a conventional database?

Performance-testing the Google I/O site ‚Äî Imagine if a restaurant told you: ‘We spend 20 minutes cooking everything you might possibly ask for so when you pick something, we can give it to you instantly’.

How Performance Became the Nemesis of the Secure Python Code ‚Äî Nothing forecasts the future of a programming language better than the epos of its community. For Python, one word dominates: performance.

Components are Pure Overhead ‚Äî I explore the cost of components in JavaScript frameworks and ask whether components are just overhead?

Boosting Dropbox upload speed and improving Windows‚Äô TCP stack ‚Äî As a result, Microsoft improved the Windows implementation of the TCP RACK-TLP algorithm and its resilience to packet reordering.

I forgot how to spellcheck ‚Äî My project has ultimately failed. All I am left with is some insights on the spellchecking problem and I am sharing them now.

Chia mining can allegedly wreck a 512 GB SSD in forty days

Avoiding concept spill in API design (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Assuming an understanding of internal concepts in order to use an API significantly increases the user‚Äôs cognitive load.

SSHing to my Raspberry Pi 400 from a browser, with Cloudflare Tunnel and Auditable Terminal ‚Äî Using Cloudflare Tunnel and Auditable Terminal to connect to a Pi 400 at my home network using nothing more than a browser.

55,000+ lines of Rust code later: A debugger is born! ‚Äî The Record & Debug Tool (rd), a record/replay debugger written in Rust, has entered alpha.

Transport vs Network ‚Äî In today‚Äôs public Internet it appears to matter a lot that the transport protocol header is visible to the network.

The game that almost died during COVID and how I made it an app ‚Äî A reflection on 1 year of writeydrawey.

Someone mailed an AirTag to themselves to see if they could track its route ‚Äî Capturing it’s location every 2 minutes, I am trying to figure out the route of a letter by regular mail.

Distraction free writing with Emacs

Reverse Engineering an Unknown Microcontroller ‚Äî From nothing to a full SDK in one week flat!

#indie biz

a unified theory of low/no code, middleware, and the future of enterprise applications (Feb 2021) ‚Äî Why is Salesforce unbundling itself? What are the implications for the future of enterprise software?

The Psychology of Clubhouse’s User Retention (…and Churn) ‚Äî A semi-humourous case study into the psychology of user retention. Via TheSlice.

The new rules of the creator economy ‚Äî Social media platforms used to get most of their content for free. That dynamic is changing.

Don’t build products, build relationships ‚Äî In order to validate your product idea, you have to first forget about it and start building relationships.

Do you know how often people have the problem you help them solve? ‚Äî The natural frequency of the problem your product solves helps gauge what‚Äôs too little and what‚Äôs too much.

#science

Quantum Entanglement Has Now Been Directly Observed at a Larger Macroscopic Scale ‚Äî Another link: Minuscule drums push the limits of quantum weirdness

Sharks Use the Earth‚Äôs Magnetic Field Like a Compass ‚Äî Someone finally figured out how to prove these animals rely on magnetic sensing to migrate across oceans.

3,000-Year-Old Submerged Settlement Discovered in Switzerland ‚Äî Humans may have inhabited the Lake Lucerne area 2,000 years earlier than previously thought

Measuring time accurately increases the entropy in the universe ‚Äî The better a clock is at timekeeping, the more entropy it will produce in the form of heat.

How Gravity Is a Double Copy of Other Forces ‚Äî An enigmatic connection between the forces of nature is allowing physicists to explore gravity‚Äôs quantum side.

Mind-boggling magnets could unlock plentiful power ‚Äî Powerful magnets are bringing nuclear fusion a step closer.

How Mathematicians Use Homology to Make Sense of Topology ‚Äî Originally devised as a rigorous means of counting holes, homology provides a scaffolding for mathematical ideas.

New images of Jupiter reveal some of the planet’s mysterious features ‚Äî Unique atmospheric features of the gas giant include superstorms, cyclones and the Great Red Spot.

One of the World‚Äôs Longest-Running Experiments Sends Up Sprouts ‚Äî After lying dormant in buried bottles for 142 years, 11 seeds germinated after scientists planted them.

Neural implant lets paralyzed person type by imagining writing ‚Äî A paralyzed individual hit 90 characters per minute, 99% accuracy.

The Promise and Perils of Insect Farming ‚Äî Insect farming is on the rise. The industry is now building insect farms on a huge new scale.

#life

Privacy Implications of Accelerometer Data ‚Äî Accelerometer data from smartphones can reveal location, passwords, body features, age, gender, level of intoxication, driving style, and reconstruct words. Reddit.

It Began as an AI-Fueled Dungeon Game. It Got Much Darker ‚Äî The game touted its use of the GPT-3 text generator. Then the algorithm started to generate disturbing stories.

My email workflow in Fastmail ‚Äî Customising your email setup to be less noisy and more productive.

Boot Vector ‚Äî A history of the live CD form factor that changed linux forever.

The Wolf Tree and the World Wide Web ‚Äî Reflections on parenting, climate change, and the networks at the heart of the forest.

The Neuroscience of Busyness ‚Äî We‚Äôre biased towards doing more than doing less.

Contribution and abundance ‚Äî A remarkable response to a question about joy and happiness.

The Great Online Game ‚Äî How to Win the Internet.

Japan‚Äôs Rikunabi Scandal Shows The Dangers of Privacy Law Loopholes ‚Äî A job-seeking platform calculated and sold algorithmic scores which predicted how likely individual job applicants would decline a job offer.

How I overcame my hatred for small talk ‚Äî There are generic questions that you can ask new people, which often lead to interesting stories.

Personal systems, productivity, and slippers ‚Äî A reflection on personal tooling and how people have different expectations about them.

#random

GRIDENTIFY ‚Äî A tiny online puzzle game.

Low Poly Landscapes ‚Äî These look like half-finished renderings by the machine that’s simulating our universe.

Flatpack of morphing pasta for sustainable food packaging and greener cooking ‚Äî Flatpacked pasta that inflates itself during cooking. Yes, really!

A Feather in her Cap ‚Äî A global trade in feathers, with London at its heart, saw hundreds of millions of birds killed every year. Emily Williamson waged a long and furious campaign against it.

Black holes, buckyballs and boxing hares ‚Äî April‚Äôs best science images ‚Äî The month‚Äôs sharpest science shots, selected by¬†Nature‚Äôs¬†photo team.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, I’d love it if you shared this newsletter with a friend or two.

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me! I’d love to give them some exposure too.

Happy reading!
Beng

item.title: Interesting Things #3 ‚Äî JavaScript optimizing compiler
item.description:
Welcome to the third edition of Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie business, science, and adjacents.

These are things I came across during my Internet wanderings. I find them interesting, and I hope you do too. Enjoy!

#tech

A JavaScript optimizing compiler ‚Äî Transpiling from javascript to C++, optimising it and transpiling back to javascript resulted in faster performance.

Scaling monorepo maintenance ‚Äî Modularising an internal git index increased speed by 6 times.

Experiences working with an Outsourced Dev Shop ‚Äî If there was one constant from all of their failures, it was their utter refusal to take responsibility for any of it.

Applications from the Future ‚Äî An exploration of what future web applications could evolve to.

Why programmers don‚Äôt write documentation ‚Äî We don’t write documentation because writing clearly is extremely hard.

Evolution of random number generators ‚Äî Prime powers have a kinda chaotic pattern in their bits. We bootstrap this idea into a good random number generator, recapitulating history.

Rethinking the JavaScript ternary operator (Mar 2021) ‚Äî Lots of people treat the ternary operator with suspicion. What if there’s more to ternaries than meets the eye?

The Pains of Path Parsing ‚Äî A semi-deep dive into the finer points of path parsing and rendering in web applications

Build a giant live scrolling tickertape display from WS2812B Neopixels and an Arduino Uno ‚Äî Display live scrolling sports scores, crypto prices, or hot tweets on the side of your favorite newspaper building.

Problem space. Shipping space. ‚Äî I‚Äôve always made it a point to have one meeting a week focused on production.

How much traffic comes from the front page of Hacker News? ‚Äî Hopefully this post will shed some light on this topic.

Open-sourcing Remotebear, a remote jobs aggregator ‚Äî See how someone else built their app.

Easy and Ethical Traffic Monitoring with GoAccess ‚Äî If you’re looking for an easy solution and you’re conscious of user privacy, try one of these.

CSS Generators ‚Äî CSS generators can avoid some time-consuming tasks.

Linear Clock: Solar ‚Äî A clock that shows a progress bar measuring the percentage of the day elapsed since sunrise.

Branchless Coding in Go ‚Äî Why does this matter? Performance and security.

Putting an old digital clock (with an outdoor thermometer) on steroids ‚Äî Reverse engineering a thermometer sensor and replacing it with modern hardware.

The art of solving problems with Monte Carlo simulations ‚Äî Using the power of randomness to answer scientific questions.

Competitive Analysis For Product Engineers ‚Äî One of the most useful skills that an engineer can have.

The Process is not the Product (Feb 2021) ‚Äî The Software Methodology Anti-Manifesto. Leading not Managing. Dialog not Dictation

Marketing and sales intelligence with Elixir at PepsiCo (Apr 2021) ‚Äî A case study of how Elixir is being used in production.

Why Every Developer Should Start Programming With C ‚Äî Let me explain why learning C is the best choice.

The compiler will optimize that away (Apr 2021) ‚Äî Industry best practices still revolve around object oriented programming which does not perform well on modern hardware.

Migrating From Python to Kotlin for Our Backend Services ‚Äî We needed to find a new tech stack. Learn how we compared all the options and chose Kotlin.

A SQL database and an interactive grapher in a single HTML file ‚Äî Generate stand-alone HTML files embedding everything from the database to the query engine and grapher.

TCP/IP Fingerprinting for VPN and Proxy Detection (Mar 2021) ‚Äî TCP/IP fingerprinting becomes interesting again from a security perspective.

Six years of professional Clojure development ‚Äî Listing some of the strengths and weaknesses in everyday real-life use of the language and its ecosystem.

#indie biz

My Startup Failed Six Years Ago. I‚Äôve Been Hiding from My Shame Ever Since. ‚Äî Millions of people listened to my startup‚Äôs story. This is what happened after everything fell apart.

Is a computer science side project worth the effort? ‚Äî You spend most of your day in front of a screen already. Why start a side project?

We need a career path for invention ‚Äî While science and business have functioning career paths, invention does not.

Counterintuitive Lessons on How to Get Better as You Scale ‚Äî Twilio CEO and co-founder Jeff Lawson shares a set of unconventional company building lessons.

Creators are making bank selling Google spreadsheets ‚Äî Indie makers are generating tens of thousands of dollars by selling info products built on Google Sheets, Notion, and Airtable.

#science

Dozens of viruses seem to use a different DNA base ‚Äî Odd form of DNA helps viruses resist their host’s defenses.

‘Plain of Jars’, one of the most mysterious archaeological sites, reveals its true age

Internal Combustion Engine ‚Äî A stunning explanation of how these everyday, yet intricate, devices work. Lots of beautiful interactive diagrams.

What We‚Äôre Learning About Ingenuity‚Äôs Flight Control and Aerodynamic Performance ‚Äî The helicopter relies on a set of flight control algorithms that were developed before Ingenuity was even launched to Mars.

Researchers Recycle Lithium-Ion Batteries via Simple Electrolysis ‚Äî Batteries can be restored to almost new condition without the need to crush, dissolve, or melt their materials.

How Humanity Gave Itself an Extra Life ‚Äî Between 1920 and 2020, the average human life span doubled. How did we do it?

Persuading the Body to Regenerate Its Limbs ‚Äî Deer can regrow their antlers, and humans can replace their liver. What else might be possible?

#life

What Makes Music Universal ‚Äî Music brings us together to show us how different we are.

The Man Who Put His Head Inside A Particle Accelerator While It Was Switched On ‚Äî At first, he felt no pain. He knew what had happened, as he had seen a light ‚Äúbrighter than a thousand Suns". Remarkably, he did not die.

Can you make yourself sound more attractive? ‚Äî Many nationalities recognise that there is a tone of voice that is instantly alluring, but do some speakers have an unfair advantage?

80/20 is the new Half-Ass ‚Äî Don’t spend your life spraying 20% effort all over the place only to look back and wonder why you never hit 100% on anything.

The Incredible, Underrated Allen Wrench ‚Äî Six contact surfaces means less chance of slipping and stripping. This may also be why an Allen wrench feels strangely more satisfying.

On Wasting Time ‚Äî To come up with great ideas, one has to waste a great amount of time.

The company where colleagues decide your salary ‚Äî A software firm in Argentina is trying a radical experiment in employee transparency and democracy.

On the Link Between Great Thinking and Obsessive Walking ‚Äî Why does walking help us think?

#random

Hand-drawn world map of borders

Mazette ‚Äî Mesmerizing mazes. Let the maze decide for you.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, please subscribe (if you haven’t already). Or else, follow me on twitter to get the same content throughout the week.

Also, I’d love it if you shared this newsletter with a friend or two.

Have a great weekend!

item.title: Interesting Things #2 ‚Äî Can you trust floating-point arithmetic on Apple Silicon?
item.description:
Hi!

Welcome to the second edition of Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie business, science, and adjacents.

These are things I came across during my Internet wanderings. I find them interesting, and I hope you do too.

I don’t know what happened this week but I came across a LOT of stuff (60!). I didn’t do anything different so perhaps it’s just a statistical anomaly.

In any case, happy reading!

#tech

Can you trust floating-point arithmetic on Apple Silicon? ‚Äî Surprisingly, it’s wrong on both Intel and Apple Silicon, but wrong in the same way. And that’s alright.

LCH colors in CSS: what, why, and how? (April 2020) ‚Äî Lightness-Chroma-Hue (aka HCL) has a wider gamut and is better aligned with human perception.

How software gets color wrong (Dec 2020) ‚Äî The reason is that color processing in most software is based on how CRT displays in the 1990s worked.

Windows Subsystem for Linux GUI Architecture ‚Äî A look at the linux GUI stack within Windows.

Introducing git-xargs: an open source tool to update multiple GitHub repos ‚Äî With a single command.

15 Graphs You Need to See to Understand AI in 2021 ‚Äî If you want a birds eye view about jobs, publications, diversity, and more.

PlayStation Portable Architecture ‚Äî A comprehensive write-up of the gaming console from yesteryear.

2FA is missing a key feature ‚Äî When my 2FA code is entered incorrectly I‚Äôd like to know about it.

What Is Sleepminting And Will It Ruin NFT Provenance? ‚Äî Someone found a way to partially forge NFTs. News. More info.

What I wish somebody told me when I was learning Haskell ‚Äî If Haskell is such an advanced and effective language why do we not see a much wider commercial adoption?

Disasters I’ve seen in a microservices world ‚Äî Too much microservices.

Web developer’s guide to AVIF images ‚Äî The next iteration of image file formats.

semgrep ‚Äî Language-aware code search and analysis tool.

Beyond Calibri: Finding Microsoft‚Äôs next default font ‚Äî We‚Äôve commissioned five original, custom fonts to eventually be the default. Meet Tenorite, Bierstadt, Skeena, Seaford, and Grandview.

Geometric foundations of Deep Learning ‚Äî An attempt to unify a broad class of ML problems from the perspectives of symmetry and invariance.

Cherry‚Äôs First Mechanical Laptop Switches Improved My Typing Speed, Comfort ‚Äî Mechanical keyboard … on a laptop.

Unpasswords (Feb 2021) ‚Äî Go password-less. Use email instead.

Let’s light it üî• up! ‚Äî Cute animation using emoji as sprites. Non-javascript. Another one.

Blinding My Roomba ‚Äî To make it work better.

Ghost in the Shell ‚Äì Part 5 ‚Äî Some useful CLI tips.

Why People Are Afraid Of The DOM? ‚Äî Gently explaining an oddity of web development for people who aren’t web developers.

#indie biz

The Factory Is The Product ‚Äî Getting better at making the thing makes the thing better.

Pory turns 1 - Our in transit journey to 100k in MRR ü•≥ ‚Äî A no-code tool for creating sites using Airtable.

What I Learned Buying Billboards for a Startup ‚Äî Anecdotes for first time buyers of outdoor advertising.

A Path to the Minimum Viable Product ‚Äî An MVP tree is a way of methodically breaking your mission into smaller components and formulating MVP candidates.

Top 5 Product and Management skills ‚Äî SQL, Excel, Clear Communication, Story, Prioritization.

Why Every Founder Should Sell Before They Have a Product ‚Äî The best learning happens with customers.

#science

Large-scale origami locks into place under pressure ‚Äî A new method for designing large enclosures that can be deployed and locked into shape through inflation.

Latest Neural Nets Solve World‚Äôs Hardest Equations Faster Than Ever Before ‚Äî New approaches to solve entire families of partial differential equations and make it easier to model complicated systems.

The Secret Mission To Unearth Part Of A 142-Year-Old Experiment ‚Äî An unusual long-term experiment started in 1879 and is handed from one generation to the next.

NASA’s Perseverance Mars Rover Extracts First Oxygen From Red Planet ‚Äî Another step on the way to future human exploration of the Red Planet.

So You Want to Learn Physics, Second Edition ‚Äî If you are inspired and want to learn physics but don’t know where to start.

So You Want to Study Philosophy

Dolphins learn the ‚Äònames‚Äô of their friends to form teams ‚Äî The marine mammals have a sense of team membership.

Getting Sick for the Sake of Advancing Medical Research ‚Äî The first Covid-19 human challenge trial has begun in the U.K. Here‚Äôs what past trials have been like for participants.

Underwater Volcanoes Generate Enough Energy to Power the Entire US ‚Äî These powerful eruptions can teach us about how life may have formed on Earth.

The science of why the sun makes us feel so happy ‚Äî After a winter spent indoors, time in the sunshine is just what the doctor ordered.

These cellular clocks help explain why elephants are bigger than mice ‚Äî Tiny timekeepers in our cells might govern body size, lifespan and ageing.

Cosmic Map of Ultrahigh-Energy Particles Points to Long-Hidden Treasures ‚Äî How to identify the colossal monsters that create ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays?

Middle East Egyptologists uncover rare tombs from before the Pharaohs

Octopus ‚ÄòTeachers‚Äô Demonstrate They Feel Emotional Pain ‚Äî Octopi have feelings too.

15 French volunteers leave cave after 40 days without daylight or clocks ‚Äî Two thirds wanted to stay longer. Another link.

The history of lithium, and its remarkable impact on mood disorders ‚Äî It’s taken, in the form of a pill, by thousands of people every day.

A Backdoor Lets the Immune System Monitor the Brain ‚Äî A newfound hub of immune system activity at the back of the brain solves a century-old puzzle.

The Puzzling Power of Simple Arithmetic ‚Äî Playing with arithmetic can lead us to unexpected and profound discoveries.

Do Brain Implants Change Your Identity? ‚Äî Yes, but it’s complicated.

The clockwork universe: is free will an illusion? ‚Äî A growing chorus of scientists and philosophers argue that free will does not exist. Could they be right?

#life

Welcome to the YOLO Economy ‚Äî Burned out and flush with savings, some workers are quitting stable jobs in search of postpandemic adventure.

Month 6, Day 1: Fridge still off (Happy Earth Day) ‚Äî This person tries living without a fridge. It’s been six months and counting.

Jacob Ziv‚Äôs Algorithms Have Powered Decades of Compression ‚Äî The story of Jacob Ziv and the abridged history of compression.

Do Things That Will Surpass Your Life ‚Äî Lately, the fact that I‚Äôm going to die one day very much bothered me.

Don’t consume news in the morning ‚Äî You are more productive and you will get more work done at the beginning of your day.

The Best Note-Taking Method is the One You Have with You ‚Äî A lesson from photography to the world of note-taking.

On using to-do lists efficiently ‚Äî Principles I gathered from years of (mis)using to-do lists.

Impostor Syndrome: The Reason You Feel Like a Fraud ‚Äî Feeling like a fraud? Like an impostor? We all do. But we shouldn’t.

Talkers and doers ‚Äî Whenever I find myself talking and not doing, I do myself a huge favor. I shut the hell up.

A Microsoft Excel influencer is making 6 figures from her unconventional way of teaching spreadsheet hacks, tips, and tricks ‚Äî aka Miss Excel.

#random

Quandaries of Quinine ‚Äî A medicinal commonly available in tonic water has a disputed history.

Squeezebox Keyboard ‚Äî Another wacky custom-made split ergonomic keyboard.

bridges, maps & memories ‚Äî Historical network visualizations over maps, a map of Reddit and a new website.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, I’d love it if you shared this newsletter with a friend or two.

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me! I’d love to give them some exposure too.

Happy reading! Beng

item.title: Interesting Things #1 ‚Äî The Adjacent Possible
item.description:
Welcome to the very first edition of Interesting Things, a curation of interesting stories and links from tech, indie business, science, and adjacents.

These are things I came across during my Internet wanderings. I find them interesting, and I hope you do too. Enjoy!

#tech

The Adjacent Possible (May 2020) ‚Äî Each technology or innovation enables new possibilities in adjacent areas. When multiple disparate enablers exert influence in the same adjacent area, then breakthroughs can arise seemingly out of nowhere.

Morpheus Turns a CPU Into a Rubik‚Äôs Cube to Defeat Hackers ‚Äî Encrypting pointers and rotating the key every 100 milliseconds makes it hack-resistant. It would have stopped Spectre and Meltdown with only a 10% overhead.

Rust in Production: MeiliSearch ‚Äî Read a real-life experience with Rust and discover tips for your own open source project.

How To Make Tree Shakeable Libraries ‚Äî Write javascript so that unused code can be excluded, and how to verify it.

Faster Python with Go shared objects (the easy way) ‚Äî A python developer wanted faster code and wrote it in Go instead.

No one wants to manage Kubernetes anymore ‚Äî More and more companies decide they don’t want to deal with the complexity of managing server clusters in-house.

Pixel Physics ‚Äî Physics simulated by cellular automata. Play with pixels and see them falling down.

Content-aware image resizing in JavaScript ‚Äî A demonstration of how the Seam Carving algorithm works. It’s a bit like magic.

Lessons learned from seven years of open-source database development ‚Äî I started a lightweight, open-source, distributed relational database for fun, but it‚Äôs since become something more serious.

NFT Canon ‚Äî A list of readings and resources on all things NFTs, curated by a16z.

Shedding light on fairness in AI with a new data set ‚Äî Facebook publishes a dataset of of 45,186 human face-to-face videos with an emphasis on fairness and diversity across age, gender, skin tone, & ambient lighting.

#indie biz

Evaluating Side Hustles ‚Äî An affiliate SaaS site was built and sold 18 months later for $150,000 (estimated). Let’s look at the numbers. (Independent case study)

How to build an app, get acquired by GitHub, buy an app back from GitHub and then sell it again ‚Äî The story of Speaker Deck.

#science

These Ants Shrink Their Brains for a Chance to Become Queen ‚Äî If their bids at motherhood fail, they can then regrow their brains. Another link.

A robotic spacecraft just latched onto an active satellite in orbit ‚Äî By providing renewed power and navigation control, the lifespan has been extended for five more years.

Does the Universe have higher dimensions? Part 2

The scientists turning the desert green (Mar 2021) ‚Äî In China, scientists have turned vast swathes of arid land into a lush oasis. Now a team of maverick engineers want to do the same to the Sinai.

Whitest-ever paint could help cool heating Earth, study shows ‚Äî New paint reflects 98% of sunlight as well as radiating infrared heat into space, reducing need for air conditioning

Scientists 3D print graphene aerogels that purify water at scale ‚Äî The novel material is capable of removing dyes, metals and organic solvents from drinking water with 100% efficiency.

A New Twist Reveals Superconductivity‚Äôs Secrets (Mar 2021) ‚Äî An unexpected superconductor was beginning to look like a fluke, but a new theory and a second discovery have revealed that emergent quasiparticles may be behind the effect.

Laser-equipped robots that zap weeds on farmland ‚Äî The machine is the latest form of automation to arrive in agriculture.

Bridges, highways, scaffolds: The amazing engineering of army ants ‚Äî How these tiny, blind ants manage to coordinate these dynamic constructions remains largely unknown, but a new study brings us closer to the answer.

#life

Trapped in the technologist factory ‚Äî Reflections on working in the software industry.

Napping in the afternoon can improve memory and alertness ‚Äì here‚Äôs why (Feb 2021)

How to (finally) find a productivity system that works for you ‚Äî Figuring this out unstuck me from chasing the perfect method and focus on what really matters ‚Äì getting things done.

Do things, tell people ‚Äî These are the only things you need to do to be successful.

#random

Data Visualization Guide ‚Äî A guide for producing infographics and data visualisations based on the works of Edward Tufte and Stephen Few.

WindowSwap ‚Äî Look out of other people’s windows.

#end

If you enjoyed these stories, I’d love it if you shared this newsletter with a friend or two.

And should you come across anything interesting in your wanderings, please email or tweet me! I’d love to give them some exposure too.
